For balance, I have to say a few words against metric as well - speaking as someone who went through the conversion process at school (several times - they kept changing the unit's!).

Firstly, there's nothing magic or correct about the metric system, it's basically just an accident of history. The French adopted it as a part of their 'rational' revolution, and Bonaparte then imposed it on half of Europe. So, when our technological development reached the stage where we obviously needed a more rational and universal system, there was an 'obvious' one waiting to be chosen. We didn't think about designing a more useful and appropriate system, we just took the one that was already there - with all its drawbacks.

And there are plenty of drawbacks. First it's base 10 - presumably because we have ten fingers. So we have a wonderful, modern, scientific measuring system, based entirely on an accident of nature that gave us five digits on each hand and foot. The end result is that we have a universal system that can't be divided by 3 and 4 - two if the most basic requirements of any such system. It's no accident that so many of the original measuring/counting systems were based on 12 - it's just so much easier to use. If only we had 12 fingers!

OK, measuring things in twelves doesn't give us the principle advantage of decimal - the ability to just to move the decimal point - but, had we bitten the bullet and switched to base 12, we would have had the advantages of both systems.

Then there's the size of the units. Meters are too big, centimeters are too small, and millimeters are just plain silly. My father worked as an engineer for Ford Europe, dealing with both German and British engineers, and he had constant problems with German parts that weren't machined accurately enough, because they worked in millimeters, whereas their British counterparts used thousands of an inch. And in everyday life you need 'human sized' units - it's no accident that the old system tended to come up with measurements like the inch and foot - much more useful than the 'too big, too small' bloody metric system. When we originally went metric, we chose the centimetre as our base unit, as it was more human friendly than the meter and miliimetre, but then we moved over to the 'proper' units, and now you have the bizarre situation that trailers and railway waggons, which are 20 to 30 feet long are measured to the nearest millimeter!! For most construction projects, standard measures are much faster and more intuitive. What is half of a half? A quarter. What is half of a quarter? One eighth. Simple and easy because the standard measure was developed at a time before mathematics was taught to common folk. Asking a fifteenth century carpenter to calculate to the nearest tenth of a unit would have resulted in a funny look and little work getting done. Metric units are great for engineering because they are easy to layout on paper and easy to transfer when it comes time to build the actual machines. One major issue arises when working in the field, however. Metric tapes only go down to millimeters and if the calculation requires finer measures, regular old joes will not have the tools in their toolboxes to make those finer adjustments. Regardless, for aircraft and spacecraft or any vehicle in general, matric is the way to go. Building houses and other structures, standard is quicker and probably more efficient.
